content.caption: Disclosure: Journalists aren’t great at prognostication. So, instead of predicting what storylines to watch in 2015, we offer the following questions to answer over the next 12 months. From new faces in Washington to drug epidemics at home, the coming year offers a fair share of promises to fulfill and challenges to overcome. Our resolution? To keep you informed all the way through. We wish you a safe and happy new year.
And in the year that was? See what we chose for the top stories of 2014.

2.heading: Is this the year Maine goes to pot?

content.caption: Jeff Clapp gives a pot plant a sniff during an April event in Bangor about growing medical marijuana at home. In 2015, it’s possible that Maine could legalize the drug for all purposes.

Another effort for legalizing pot will go before Maine lawmakers this year, while two coalitions are passing around clipboards seeking signatures to put the same question before the electorate in 2016. In Portland and South Portland, ordinances nominally legalizing the recreational use of the drug were approved by voters in 2013 and 2014, respectively. Medical marijuana in Maine is a booming business, with new product lines forming (including edibles and superconcentrated “honey oil”) which foreshadows the inevitable legalization showdown. All of this intrigue begs one question: Will 2015 or 2016 be the year that Maine says “yea” to pot?

3.heading: What’s ahead for Mr. Poliquin in Washington?

content.caption: Bruce Poliquin speaks at his victory press conference at the Oakland House of Pizza. All eyes are now on the freshman Congressman as he slices his way through Washington.

After an energetic, but disciplined campaign, former state treasurer Bruce Poliquin handily defeated Emily Cain to become Maine’s newest member of Congress and the first Republican to hold the seat in 20 years. Poliquin now occupies a coveted seat in Maine politics, one which has been a springboard for legendary names like Margaret Chase Smith, Bill Cohen, Olympia Snowe and John Baldacci. His predecessor, U.S. Rep. Mike Michaud, was lauded for his across-the-aisle deal-making and amiable demeanor. Now, all eyes are on Poliquin as we watch how he’ll make his name in Washington.
David Flanagan, the interim president at the University of Southern Maine, faced student uprising in 2014. Will these tensions subside, or inflame, in 2015?

Two distinct lines have been drawn at the University of Maine system: the faculty and rebellious students on one side, and the administration on the other. In 2015, UMaine trustees will make more serious decisions to bring its budget into balance, including perhaps closing the system’s central office in downtown Bangor. Last year, the system pressed ahead despite protests and controversy, the epicenter of which seemed to be the University of Southern Maine, where five programs and more than 50 faculty positions were eliminated. Late in the year, though, the system’s surprising decision to recommend divestment from coal -- a cause celebre among student activists -- might hint at olive branches to come.
By the time this sign was removed in the early hours of Nov. 5, Maine Democrats had lost three statewide races, extending a losing streak dating back to 2006.

When dawn broke on Nov. 5, Democrats had lost races for governor and U.S. senator, for U.S. Congress in the vast 2nd District, and control of the Maine Senate. It was the latest evidence the party that dominated Maine politics for decades is in a period of decline. (A Democrat last won a statewide campaign in 2006.)  With the challenge of rebuilding its base as Gov. Paul LePage, fresh from a resounding re-election victory, sets the state's political agendas, what is the future path for the Maine Democratic Party? And who will chart it? It’s a question a new slate of Democratic leaders -- the party cleaned house after its election losses -- must answer.
An all-too-common sight in Maine in 2014: police officers in hazardous materials suits, pawing through evidence of a meth lab. This one was on Birch Street in Bangor in November.

For many years, methamphetamine was a Maine rarity. Not that designer drugs were unknown in the Pine Tree State, but meth -- a scourge elsewhere in the country, and featured prominently in television’s “Breaking Bad” -- was not a Maine problem. Until now. With 28 small home laboratories for making meth found and busted this past year, a new state record, it’s clear that meth is taking hold. In 2014, law enforcement in Maine received nearly $1 million from a federal grant to target methamphetamine. This coming year, police and regulators must address this epidemic head-on. Too much is known about what meth has done in other states to behave any differently.
Posters for Kahbang hanging in downtown Bangor, on the day the festival announced its ultimately unsuccessful move to Portland.

The collective groan heard from Bangor this summer emanated from devotees of KahBang, a homegrown music and arts festival, when its organizers suddenly announced the shindig was moving to Portland. KahBang ultimately was canceled. Now, although KahBang still technically exists, the 2014 festival organizers Josh Gass and Meg Shorette have moved onto other projects, like their marketing company The Beta Agency, a soon-to-launch non-profit arts incubator, and the Central Gallery, a small venue in  downtown Bangor. Will any events under the KahBang banner re-emerge in 2015? It remains to be seen.
Arcade Fire was one of the summer headliners in Bangor.

The growth of Bangor as an outdoor concert venue has transformed the waterfront and made the city a summertime destination. When Phish, the Dave Matthews Band or Lady Antebellum take the stage, the Queen City has made them feel welcome. The same isn’t as true with other acts, like the thumping bass of Lil Wayne or clashing metal screams of the Rise Above festival or Rob Zombie, which prompt complaints and anger from neighbors sick of the noise. This puts city leaders in an awkward place, trying to build out Bangor’s brand while preserving its delicate quality of life. Meanwhile, Waterfront Concerts is growing in Portland, with a new outdoor concert venue and expanded use of city's waterfront for outdoor music. Will 2015 see changes in where and how Maine's music lovers get their warm-weather fix?

10.heading: Will there be another boom fishery?

content.caption: An elver fisherman sorts his catch at the peak of the fishery’s boom in 2013. Will another marine gold rush arrive in 2015?

In 2014, the elver (glass eel) boom lost steam, taking profits and the weird gray market for the tiny, slippery creatures with it. Maine has seen these boom-or-bust fisheries in the past, as today’s unloved sea creature becomes tomorrow’s must-have delicacy. If another one occurs in 2015, efforts should be made to ensure any marine gold rush is sustainable.

11.heading: What does papermaking in Maine now mean?

content.caption: The Great Northern mill in Millinocket, at the peak of its productivity.

There is no mill in Millinocket. In East Millinocket, the mill is awaiting judgment. Old Town is running again. Bucksport is being sold for scrap. Still, from Madawaska to Westbrook, Maine mills are churning out paper products. (One, in Baileyville, is actually expanding.) After a tumultuous 2014, however, what does making paper in Maine now mean? Newsprint is past, and coated paper-- like that in magazines and catalogs -- is slowing. Pulp seems vibrant and tissue, despite international competition, seems hopeful. This year, the industry must take time to solidify its footing and recognize what niches it can fill.

12.heading: Whither the Katahdin Woods national park?

content.caption: Lucas St. Clair on his land east of Baxter State Park, and where a new national park is envisioned.

Progress toward creating a national park east of Baxter State Park is moving much like the glacial ice that shaped the land. The leading advocate of the plan, Lucas St. Clair, is hiring a part-time “outreach coordinator” to talk up the park’s attributes and benefits in the Katahdin region, a slight nod toward a growing professional operation to support its existence. Meanwhile, the Penobscot Indian Nation has announced its backing of the park, and called on Maine’s U.S. Senators to draft legislation for its existence. Neither has jumped aboard, however, but as the region’s economy continues to struggle, the park’s appeal only seems to increase. What will 2015 bring?
Interested in the year that was? Read our top stories of 2014.
